The C-Pen Reader. 

Reviewing the basics using a simple book with motivating topic. 

This pen can help students to read books independently with practice, practice and practice. 

Scan words, sentences and paragraphs to read out loud. 

The screen highlights words as it converts text to speech. 

Other features include: dictionary, recorder and scan to import into a document. 

Different settings for left or right hand, speed, volume, etc.

First annual Adapted Toy Wonderland … take a peek.

124 switch adapted toys 

40 volunteers 

75 family nominations ( minus sickness … it’s the season! ) 

And the best team of staff, volunteers and FAMILIES! 

@goboardmaker visuals around the event 

Stick around for part 2 and 3 to check out the entire event.

Part 2 ✌🏻 of the Adapted Toy Wonderland event! 

❄️ Sibling’s shop - A station where siblings shopped for themselves or others.

❄️ Accessible gift wrapping - volunteers wrapped the toy in tissue paper and placed in a  plain white bag. The family or shopper picked bow color and tissue paper color to personalize. They looked BEAUTIFUL! 

❄️ Trial switch drop off - a volunteer cleaned and then placed back in the bin for new families. 

❄️ Photo station - A volunteer helped families take photographs. Families could use the switch and  Power Link to build a snowman.

Stick around for part three! 

All visuals created in @goboardmaker 

Communication book was PODD book utilized in a modified way through partner assisted scanning.

The final stations of Adapted Toy Wonderland. 

❄️ Families created cards using assessable crayons and traditional crayons . Cards featured children and teens using switch adapted toys and items created by @drawntoaac . There were three variations. 

❄️ Families then moved on to the switch adapted spinart where they created a snowflake ornament.

There were low tech and med-tech communication support options around each station.

Make sure to check out part 1 and 2 if you missed it!

Hey Santa… it’s a freebie! Link in our stories. 

Help your child communicate with Santa this holiday season using this communication bracelet. (Several vocabulary options available). 

Adults and AAC users can wear to model and pair alongside a robust communication system. Here are just a few ideas 💡:

🎄Say hello and goodbye to Santa close up or from a distance ( greetings should be optional) 

🎄Talking about emotions ( Santa can make some really happy and for others really scared) 

🎄Asking questions about his reindeer and making reindeer food ( throw in oatmeal with any glitter ) 

🎄Making a list and talking about what you want for the holidays (we love to pair this with writing activities, using your speech generating device if available)

🎄Place on the tree as an ornament and communication visual to talk about presents

Which activity will you be trying this holiday season? Comment 👇and Happy Holidays!

This was created for a student who loved pulling tissues from boxes using a plastic strainer and dried baby wipes.

🐔 🎅 The gift that keeps on giving …

Switch adapted Santa hen. Sings, bounces and lays eggs. 

Adapted with an .89 stereo extension cable. An easier toy to try when adapting. Videos in my bio.

What’s your favorite top for this little Step-by-Step? 

🟣troll fuzz 
🔵rough sparkle 
🔴foam paper 
🟡felt 

These tops  twist on and off and add texture and tactile input on the button. 

Why?
🔴some kids prefer softer textures to hard or smooth

🟣switches and screens can be cold 

🟠differentiating switches through textures 

🟡letting kids choose their switch tops to match outfits or sensory needs 

🟢describing items recorded on switch, soft fur could have the Trolls song recorded or move scripts

Don’t forget! 

Joystick can be an access method by using a mouse dwell setting.

Website: Jacksonpollock.org

Device: Laptop 

Software: TD Snap 

Pageset: Core First 

Access: Mouse dwell ( if mouse hovers on button for 1 second it selects the word. )

Other notes: I did place a blue button overlay on to show where the cursor was highlighting. 

Add different grips to the joystick. Some might use their power chair joystick to control their device.

If your student has a sound, song or word they love to hear, record it on a mid-tech device.

Device: Go Talk 1  I also realize Jack Hartmann is the double N. Sorry Jack! 

Needs some ideas to model and expand language using the recoding? 

Try these ideas: 
-model questions ( Who is Jack Hartmann? What’s your favorite song ? ) 

-model comments ( I like it! Too loud ) 

-model feelings ( I’m happy, I’m embarrassed ) 

-keyboarding ( type out a song choice ) 

-model requesting ( pick a song or video ) 

-describe ( loud , funny )

Consider this the 2022 Dally Christmas card.

At least I delivered ice cream to a co-worker ? 

See you in the new year!

Five things to consider when selecting toys to switch adapt - you can do it ! 

I get a lot of questions about what toys when beginning to switch adapt. Here are my top tips.

1. Follow your child or teen’s lead. If they love Pokémon look for Pokémon toys. If they love bubbles look for bubble blowers.

2. If you’re unsure of their interests, think about the sensory experience. Do they prefer toys with movement? If so a bubble blower, ball popper or Fischer Price crab might be an option. 

3. Do they to prefer music and sounds? Think about toys that have music or characters that play theme songs such as Poppy from Trolls. Baby Einstein toys usually have lots of music options too.

4. If your child or teen prefers lights or vibration consider LED lights, a vibrating pillow or the Fischer Price chainsaw toy. 

It may be a combination of the above too. 

5. To hit or to hold? To activate some toys the child /teen must hold down the switch. Other toys activate by a single hit. Motor movement and pressure matter when selecting toys. 

💡Switch toys should be rotated- often. If you buy switch toys commercially they can be expensive and choices can be limited. 

Think about how quickly neurotypical kids become bored of a toy - even if it’s new!

Learning to adapt toys is a great skill to have. It cuts down on cost for play, alternates new toys in the playroom and allows us to follow the child/teen’s lead.

🔥🚨 back to school means back to fire drills. Link in my story to download for free.

A fire drill can impact students not only during school day but when they return home. 

Send a note home to communicate with caregivers about the fire drill at school. Two versions available. 

This half page note communicates: 

🚨 how the student may have felt during and after the drill. ( let your student help fill out the form to share feelings if able)

🚨 where or what they were doing when the drill went off. 

🚨 consider placing low-tech AAC core and feeling boards in the emergency classroom bag. ( inspired by @praacticalaac recent course on speechpathology.com )

Do you have students who love put-in or close ended tasks? 

 Create a put-in floral arrangement play opportunity this Valentine’s Day. ♥️ ❤️ 💜 The best part ? A larger container doubles as storage. 

To create your own you’ll need: 

-Tupperware container, old plastic jar, old Parmesan container. This cute Valentine’s one is from DollarTree. 

-fake flowers

-wire cutters ( to cut down stems ) 

-power drill ( to drill holes in the lid ) 

Ideas for use:
-making patterns 

-separating by color 

-making a flower arrangement via pretend play in the floral center 

-cleaning up or placing flowers in the bin, dump and do all over again! 

-modeling core words and descriptions

-count those roses! Put in one or try to fit them all in!

The Head to Toe Communication and Whole Body Communication resource will be posted for a week! 

Link in my bio under TPT. 

This one page handout can be utilized through a team approach to: 

-identify any movement a student with a complex body or communication needs might have 

-begin to identify potential responses for partner assisted scanning 

-being to plan for potential switch placements 

-gain better insight and understanding for potential access method trials 

-have client or different members of the team fill out to review movement in multiple environments 

-utilize as part of informal AAC assessment

We ❤️ this feelings board. Some of our preschoolers like to look at all the faces, have us act them out ( drama! ) and allow us to model when upset, happy, frustrated, sad and confused. 

Instead of recreating the wheel, we printed the feelings board from TD Snap communication software. 

Print from an iPad or Windows base device using these simple steps:

1. Navigate to page you want to print 

2. Edit 

3. Page 

4. Print pages 

5. Choose whether you want the toolbar, message window or visual links. 

6. Print! 

Place in your classroom emergency bag and or grab to model and explore emotions with students. 

Download the non-speaking version of this app on your desktop to edit, sync,  share and print. 

SLPs with your ASHA CCCs,  you can download TD Snap with voice for free! Directions in a story highlight.

-Little People Firetruck or Airplane ( lights, phrases and music)

Alternative Pencils ✏️ was developed by the Centre for Literacy and Disability Studies. It is for students who cannot hold a traditional pencil or use a physical keyboard to write.

It must include all 26 letters of the alphabet for students to access. There are no prerequisites such as letter knowledge or spelling skills to use. 

Students might choose their letter by alternative access methods like partner assisted scanning, eye gaze, among other ways. 

This example was created using foam board, felt letters and zip ties for PAS for a preschool student. I am sure I’ll make modifications. 

For more information check out:

http://alternativepencils.weebly.com/

Come set up a Big Candy Corn switch.

The Candy Corn is a proximity switch which activates based on movement or coming close to the switch. No physical touch needed, however you can touch the surface to activate. 

The switch can signal activation with a slight beep or lights. Make sure to turn off the battery when done in the switch. 

Candy corn is mounted on Modular Hose with clamp and paired with the Enabling Devices mini popper for some immediate feedback.

There is also a smaller version of this switch.

Use your screen as switch input on TD Snap. 

I’ve used this feature for students with visual impairments who benefit from auditory scanning and can use touch access. 

As buttons scan out loud, students can tap anywhere on the screen when they hear the button they want . 

Use one voice to scan options and the student’s voice to say the button when selected. 

How to get screen as switch input in TD Snap:
-edit 
-user 
-access method scanning 
- scan type > switch input > screen 

Additional options can also be set up for auditory scanning , high contrast and inverting options during scan.

@aacforall and I are EGGstatic about this collab and FREEBIE!🐣 

Add this communication board to your child’s Easter basket during an egg hunt to give a visual for target words or pair with their robust AAC system. Help them label items & actions, request (ex: CANDY, EGGS 🍬 ), support their ability to follow simple directions (ex: FIND it, PUT in) & more. 

✨Ideas for use:✨
-Model pointing to + saying OPEN as you open the eggs. Pause and wait to see if they can point to the target word or say OPEN themselves after modeling several times!
-Model pointing to PUT IN and BASKET as you put items in the basket
-Model pointing to WALK and LOOK as you search for the eggs 
-Label EGGS & CANDY as you find them and offer both as a choice for requesting (ex: do you want EGG (an empty one 🤪) or CANDY?
-Give a choice for how you’ll find the eggs to request while pointing to target words (ex: do you want to HOP or WALK?)

🟥🟧🟨🟩🟦🟪We ( SLP and IS ) saw these blocks from @thespecialteacher and knew we needed a sensory wall! 

Here are the details and our thoughts so far 👇🏻: 

🟥 Honeycomb blocks are from Five Below and are $5.25 for a pair of two. 

🟧 The self adhesive stickers provided were not strong enough so we used command strips.

🟨 Activation is directly in the middle, so a student could use one, two, three or their palm as long as they hit the center. 

🟩 Some students stopped to change the color , some changed in passing while others wanted to take them off . Before we make changes we are going to see what the AM group thinks. 

🟦 We both thought about putting magnets on the back for a dry erase, magnetic board so kids can mix, match and move them. 

🟪 These lasted throughout the first day. Maybe 7 color choices and different blink / fade settings. Hold two seconds to turn off and on.  Batteries for these might add up! Make sure they are turned off when not in use.

🎪 🍿 Accessible Carnival Game at our school carnival - overview and my thoughts 💭: 

-The game was roll a dice using a switch adapted spin art and large tactile dice. The dice spins and lands on a number when the switch is held down, and then students get the corresponding prize. 

-My prizes were not very thoughtful for kids who did not eat by mouth but we did have extras behind the scenes. 

-We all played the game in the same way, by holding the switch down. I really do think all students enjoyed accessing the switch and some parents and students had questions.

-I wonder if a tent , off to the side for a quiet space or sensory based game might help some of our students. A carnival is loud, busy and very overwhelming. 

-I’d love for there to be more than one accessible carnival game out of the 10. It’s a start. 

-A lot more of our preschoolers attended the carnival than I expected. I was really excited about that but this is just one tiny step to accessibility.

October 2024 at Closing the Gap … my first pre conference! 

Short abstract 👇🏻:

Following this workshop, participants will be able to describe ways to build AAC capacity in the preschool setting or with a preschool age client focusing on myths and research, vocabulary selection, aided language stimulation and goal writing ideas. The participants will review alternative access methods in order to discuss and support students with complex communication needs and access challenges in the classroom. Through a make and take portion, participants will create materials and generate ideas to increase accessibility for learning, play and communication when working with students who use alternative access methods. Lastly, participants will be able to describe ways to supports students with complex communication needs and physical challenges beyond the classroom setting through caregiver education, caregiver communication and carry-over ideas into the home setting.

Reposting some of the BEST additions to Hannah’s classroom this 2022-2023 year. Update and feedback!

Hannah, classroom teacher, was looking for some labels around the classroom and this is what we came up with in October of 2022.

These talk blocks from the Learning Company ( discontinued )  have been SO great with voice output. Most students use them, whether they are peers or students with complex communication needs. The blocks have increased communication and decreased some undesired behaviors ( we are working on it! ). 

We added more around the classroom for help to get the swing down and had a student record their sweet voice.

These do get ripped off, so we used hook and loop command strips to stick them right back up. 

Open usually gets torn down daily. We let them know we heard their communication but can’t always leave. 

These talking blocks are no longer made but people have suggested talk tiles from Amazon with similar pressure and function. 

Happy almost end of the school year 🍎💥! Go hug your intervention specialist.

@aacforall and I have teamed up to bring you this summer fun communication board! If your little one is an emerging communicator, this can help support their communication skills SO much! 

Use these visuals to support your child’s expressive and receptive language skills- whether supporting verbal speech or to pair with your child’s core board and robust language system. 

Place on a kick board, pool float or simple ziplock bag with duct tape securing at the top. We also recommend laminating first for added protection! 

☀️ Model, play and have sun in the sun! ☀️ 

Ideas: 
💧 Model pointing + verbalizing WAIT as you apply SPF 🧴 
💧Model pointing to + verbalizing IN before they jump into your arms
💧 Model pointing to + verbalizing TOWEL or SNACK to help them request what they need 
💧Model pointing to + verbalizing action words SPLASH, JUMP, FLOAT as they splash, jump & float!

Modeling without expectation can go a long way! You never know what they’ll communicate to you by pointing after pairing with a visual during fun & motivating experiences! 

Link to freebie in bio and stories! Let us know if you try this one!👇🏼 & tag a mama who needs to see! 👯

✅Be sure to follow @learnwithchatterboxes and @aacforall to learn ways to support your child’s communication skills!

I was struggling to find hands on toys and activities for  a student who didn’t always need switch access. 

I wanted to make sure the toys were safe, so my student didn’t hit themselves in the face or they toy didn’t fall on another student. 

These screw based suction cups from Amazon were an easy fix to keep the toys on the table and continue play.

Open the base of the toy, check the space between the base and inside parts of the toy and then drill a hole to insert the screw side of the suction cup. Secure with the nut in the inside.

The most fancy mount on the market 😎.

The shoebox. Upside down and painted in a matte black. Positioning and access matter! 

🖤Why?
When my client sits on the floor, I want their device to be eye level for a few reasons! 

During this session communication is the main cognitive load.

Additional reasons might be a student’s visual impairment and the best position for equipment or assisting their guided reach. 

I always love working with a teacher of the visually impaired for what works best for each student when accessing their device.

Some adapted items require students to hold down on a switch to continue activation. Once they let go of the switch the item or toy stops.

Some examples are bubble blowers, lava lamps, spin arts, Gone Fishin’ Game, dice spinners, or fans.

Check out the Tiny Switchy, a small switch interface that allows you to set a timer for your switch to latch and activate a toy. 

Set a time length from one second to 68 minutes! 

There are more modes and features but check it out on their website. I linked in my stories.

Our local theme park has a sensory bag and communication boards in their First Aid area.

The staff was INCREDIBLY kind and helpful, willing to show me the bag and contents. Thanks to my friend and PT for sharing this information. 

The bag included:
-communication board with body parts, phrases, about me, location and pain scale in English and Spanish

-noise canceling headphones 

-slime, fidgets, stacking dominos 

-adult coloring books 

-sensory balls and stuffed animals, among other things 

This bag was in a back, somewhat dark private room. I’d have to think this was on purpose to reduce stimulation but I didn’t ask. 

Does your local theme park have these bags?

This post three years ago had me thinking about movement and communication, sensory play with core and failure free learning with feedback ( a Karen Erickson term) .

Some students spin, move words up and down, read each word, play next to and even have tried to take a bite.

My main goal: experience and play with core words early and often! 

Created out of:
-PVC pipe
-pool noodles 
-PVC pipe cutter

Suction cup tape! 

Looking for a way to secure a trial or 3D printed keyguard to a speech device ? 

Suction cup tape is a great alternative to Velcro, reducing bulk and the potential residue it can leave behind. 

Swipe for my video to check out the strength and pull needed to take it off.

I typically replace every three months or so, depending on how often the keyguard is removed. Thanks for our 3D printing guru for sharing this with me!

🎨 Accessible painting for individuals who may not be able to hold a paintbrush or don’t like the mess. 

Set-up:
🔴crayola washable paint 
🟠glitter ( vision addition ) 
🟡poster board / table cloth 
🟢Remote control crab toy by BToys ( any moving toy with a motor such as a truck or walking animal will work )

How to ideas:
🔵allow your client to select colors and glitter, plop on the poster board 
🟣turn on the crab and watch it smear and track paint 
🔴cut up and add to frames 
🟠we also had fun turning the lights off too!

Create this life size fidget spinner for under 💲6️⃣from the Dollar Tree.

Items needed: 
🔸black or white foam board 
🔹pinwheels 
🔸zip ties 
🔹hot glue to secure 
🔸something sharp to cut handle off of pinwheels ( I used PVC pipe cutters ) 

Follow steps in the video! Make sure the hot glue doesn’t bleed through the hole on to the front of the poster. This will impact spin! 

If you pinwheels are dragging on the front of the poster bend them out to reduce contact and increase spin! 

Take on the playground, attach to a wall, play sitting down or standing up.

A resource to prep for the start of the school year. 🍎 🗓 🚒 

I did not print these out and was ALWAYS scrambling at the end of the day to print, fill out and send home. This is definitely an important prep activity! 

A fire drill can impact students not only during school day but when they return home. 

Send a note home to communicate with caregivers about the fire drill at school. Two versions available. 

This half page note communicates: 

🚨 how the student may have felt during and after the drill. ( let your student help fill out the form to share feelings if able)

🚨 where or what they were doing when the drill went off. 

🚨 consider placing low-tech AAC core and feeling boards in the emergency classroom bag. ( inspired by @praacticalaac recent course on speechpathology.com )

Created in @goboardmaker

Need some back to school accessible playground ideas? Check out these items and descriptions below.
(All photos from Amazon.com) 

🐸 Melissa and Doug velcro Froggy Toss - a toss and catch game where frogs can be placed on a walker, wheelchair, leg, arm, hand, etc. Ball is the soft side of Velcro. 

🫧 Switch adapted bubble blower. Want to make your own? Check out my earlier post to download the manual. 

Collapsable hammock swing. Our OT found one from the brand Ozark. It’s a great option for indoor/outdoor recess and if your school doesn’t have a swing set.

Bubble wrap. An indoor recess idea and item to place on the ground to walk or roll over with a wheelchair for some fun popping noises.

🪂 A mini parachute is a way to play with a group of kids, especially when everyone gets to go under! Kids can sit, stand or travel to go back and forth. The mini chute is also nice as a few teachers can hold.

🏖 A beach ball tied by string to the playground equipment is another way to play with a ball that is light weight and comes back. Hang high, low or create a PVC pipe stand. 

🎨 A chalk holder or extender is an idea to place on a walker or wheelchair to create art all around the playground. This is also an idea for students who do not like to get their hands messy. 

⚾️ A large exercise ball is a way for students in gait trainers, walkers or wheelchairs to push/hit at the same time, sending the big, light ball on a roll. Plus, everyone loves the giant ball to roll and bounce on with an adult. 

🎶 A large piano mat is a great indoor recess idea. Lay flat and walk or roll to create lights, sound effects and music.

Any other ideas, modifications or thoughts? Share below!

A low-cost and low-tech eye gaze idea. 

Grab a mini cookie sheet from Dollar Tree or Walmart, grab low tech symbols ( mirroring high tech ), laminate and add a magnet strip to the back. Create a grid size and options that work best for your student.

I used an old calendar magnet for my fridge and glued.

Use the back for storage.

Thinking about a wobble or leaf switch but don’t have availability to trial? 

Try this idea my AT OT taught me during a consult. Attach a piece of cardstock to a microlight. This can allow your student to move through the motion at the head, arm, leg, etc.

Go high five your amazing OT! So important for collaboration with access and language.

POP and PAINT! 

Accessible art for students who use wheelchairs, walkers, gait trainers, strollers, walk or wagons.

Lay down a layer of bubble wrap, add paint and one more layer of bubble wrap. Roll, walk or stomp across it to smear paint and an added sensory pop. 

Also an idea for students who don’t like to get their hands dirty. They can walk across the bubble wrap. 

It’s an opportunity for all students to paint in the same way.

Movement, play and communication. 

Create this parachute activity for the playground.

Use fabric transfer to add symbols on the parachute to comment, cease, continue and make choices. *Note: I only help iron on for five seconds at a time! Very thin.

Visuals included:
Up and down 
Stop, go, wait 
Under and out 
Ball 
Fast and slow 

Use partner assisted scanning to to offer choices for students, hold up for two eye gaze choices or have touch or stomp for touch access.

When your finished fold or roll into a ball and store.

Download the visuals for free on my TPT page. I’ll post later tonight.

Another free resource to get to know your students - new and old from over the summer.

Parents and caregivers can also use.  Print off a copy and send school, daycare or after school program. 

I send this one pager and note home for families to fill out. All forms go in a binder and I refer back or share with other school team members throughout the year. 

A few important questions include how to know when I’m upset, what calms me, how do I communicate at home, things I don’t like and my favorite things.

Adaptions don’t always mean mid to high tech modifications! 

Like these Play-Doh tools with PVC pipe handles. 

It’s about focusing on students’ strengths and HOW they want to access their play and environment. 

Sometimes we can use what we have and adapt:
-handles 
-size 
-angle
-colors 
-bases 
-dim lights and flashlight 
-Velcro / elastic straps 
-strings / ribbon loops 
-adding boarders and edges 
-playing with and holding toys in different ways
-playing with toys using different parts of the body ( toes, arms, head )

Turn your old food and drink packages into accessible building blocks for: 

1- An accessible block center as these boxes are light weight, can be knocked over with an arm, head, leg, wheelchair, walker, kicking and make a soft(er) sound as they fall.

2-Eye gaze and Visual considerations as these blocks are large in size, have real images and can stack tall to eye level. They can also he held apart for gaze choices to build. 

3-Environmental print gives our students something to recognize and to talk about from home. Think logos and brands. 

4-Pretend play anyone? Use these blocks for a grocery store, construction site or kitchen, among other ideas.

5-Bonus … low cost ! You can upcycle these boxes easily using what you have. Stuff with old newspaper or tissue paper and seal with packing tape. If your kids don’t love these blocks just throw in the recycling.

The Hip Talk. 

I wore this speech output device all day in preschool and these are my thoughts:

👍🏻 Loved having by my side at all times for in the moment communication. 

 👍🏻 used some common communication themes I’ve seen in the classroom… look what I have, I need help, let’s play and up.

👍🏻 voice output 

👍🏻kids could explore and use as we sat and played 

👍🏻 it was a visual reminder for me to model and assign meaning all around the classroom

👎🏻soft vocal intensity 

👎🏻a little heavy and hot to wear 

👎🏻not super clear digitized speech ( older model ) 

👎🏻limited to four phrases at a time and no where near robust. Could be one tool in our communication tool box. 

👎🏻 original Fanny pack bag did not fit around my hips! I ordered my own on Amazon for around $6. 

Overall I’m going to keep wearing the device. Voice output is powerful and this tool helps for in the moment communication and connection!  The Hip Talk plus looks like it’s worked through some of the 👎🏻 comments above! Visuals from @goboardmaker

POWER TOOLS and a switch accessible pumpkin activity. 

Original idea from my girl @kpowellslp … I just added a switch accessible power drill! 

Using the Power Select interface ( similar to a Power Link) students can activate appliances like the power drill and hair dryer to create a colorful, tactile pumpkin. ( an extra set of hands during this project is helpful! ) 

Settings include direct activation with time option and latch.

Communication ideas :

🖍 describing words like hot, shiny, sticky, dry 

🖍 describing long or short crayons and big or little hole

🖍 selecting colors 

🎃 core words like go, stop, different, put, get 

🎃 numbers for length of time to blow dry 

🎃 commenting if blow dryer or power drill are too loud 

🎃 feeling the pumpkin for sensory or tactile feedback

Day 3 of our AAC & Alternative Access mini-series with@rachelmadelslp and @aacforall and today is all about a Total Access Approach to your students and helping you to get clear on how the environment and time of day may affect which access method your student will be most successful with.

Fatigue is REAL when it comes to alt access — and if we create customized systems for students based on their needs that are not effortful and fatiguing, then we can help them be more successful communicating across different environments and communication partners. 

Strategies like verbal referencing and attributing meaning can be powerful for students as they are navigating their alternative access methods. 

And don’t forget about lite-tech AAC systems and partner assisted auditory scanning — these can be a great way to expand language skills as a student is learning and practicing an alternative access method. 

What’s partner assisted scanning all about? 

PAS alt access method where a communication partner reads through and scans items for their client to signal a choice. Language can be presented via auditory + picture support or just auditory choices. When the client hears the choice they want, they signal with their that’s it response ( e.g. head turn, kicking leg, voicing , hitting a voice output switch ). This can be completed through in the moment choices or a robust language and communication book.

Day 4 (and the final day!) of our AAC & Alternative Access mini-series with @rachelmadelslp and @aacforall and today we’re talking about what you can do TODAY to get your complex cases building strong skills to access language. 

Here are a few reminders: 
🌟 Don’t forget play! This is how students can practice their alt access method without getting burnt out and having fun 

🌟Lite-tech AAC can be just as powerful and even more robust than high-tech at times. 

🌟Respond to EVERYTHING — this is how students will learn what their body is doing and how someone is interpreting it. 

🌟Model model model— and don’t forget to provide plenty of wait time for students to initiate

“Without participation, there is no one to talk to, nothing to talk about and no reason to communicate.” 

( Beukelman & Miranda, 1998) 

We created these easy rockets  @atclosingthegap this week to increase active engagement, provide a motivating experience ( hopefully )  and for something to talk about! 

Reasons why I love this in the classroom and for communication among access methods:

- students usually need help with the rocket ( requesting assistance or gaining attention!) 

-students with access challenges can have control over something crashing, adult letting go and positioning the rocket for take off 

-fun and silly with visual feedback 

- it can go to the playground 

-counting backwards from 10 for students who love numbers ( the OG reason this rocket game to life ) 

-use it for all things they fly and go and switch out stickers and symbols 

-it’s CHEAP and easy to make

Directions are on the Solo Cup website or below:

How to make a Solo Cup Rocket:
-grab two solo cups 
-use a hole punch and put four holes in one cup
-cut two rubber bands 
-knot from one side to the other , complete again to make an X
-place rubber band cup on top of the plain cup and watch it go! 

Visual on slide two from @drawntoaac

@beautifulspeechlife and I joined up for AAC Awareness Month to talk tips when using a Step-by-Step. It’s not a communication system by any means but it’s a great way to increase engagement with voice output messages and sound effects. 

Tips to using a step by step switch 👇🏻 

💬Consider the voice - Record a voice similar in age to your client. Be sure the gender of the voice aligns with that of your client. If you aren’t sure ask for feedback by recording multiple voices gauging your client’s reaction. If you can’t seem to find a voice that feels right, ask a friend or family member! (Eg. “Do you think this is what Sam’s voice sounds like?” “If not, what should I change?”) Thanks to @transplaining for some consult time to share thoughts and ideas on this topic.

💬Provide Age Appropriate Language - think slang. For example comments: love it; eh, it’s okay; cringe, etc.

💬Add a visual to the Step-by-Step such as symbols, written words or tactile overlays

💬Make it Motivating! - provide opportunities your student/client WANTS to talk about. Think about their interests and preferences.

💬Positioning Matters - you don’t have to use a hand to access. Mount on a modular hose for head to toe positioning.

💬Think outside the box! Some ideas for using your Step-by-Step:
Repetitive book lines, favorite songs,sharing opinions, jokes and stories, sound effects and so many more.

Use the Step by Step as a means to provide more opportunities for active engagement. The best part? It’s easy and quick to change the messages making it a very versatile tool in total communication.

Do you have a student that needs a job or some movement in the hall? 

AND 

Do you need an idea to increase choice and voice for how they want to walk down the hall? 

Consider creating choices for how they can move their body down the hall. Swap them out and always offer something different if they have their own idea! 
 
Try to tie them to the curriculum. If your reading Mouse Paint, try using mouse feet or paint feet (wiping feet like you are getting paint off of those shoes) .

Tailor towards their motivators for increase in active engagement. Created in @lessonpix and now available in the sharing center.

Need some simple steps to increase accessibility at your fall festival? Check out these ideas.

1. Use visuals at your event for areas or games. These number visuals from @lessonpix could help students to count while working on their number recognition.

2. Try using a switch adapted game or PowerLink for alternative access. Use a fan to push ping pong balls for a mini golf game, a spin art to spin a dice, a hand held mixer in a tub of water for a boat race, among others! 

3. Physical modifications to games could include size of handles, size of targets or types of balls. We cut a PVC pipe in half for toss games and students could drop the ball down the pipe or hold to release ball down the pipe to aim for targets. 

4. We also provided games that could be brought to the student. An idea for students with anxiety, physical access challenges or who need a quieter area. 

5. Game variations for size, angle and gravity. These witch hats worked better for the younger population and a student could drop the ring from overtop, using gravity to their advantage. 

6. For toss and throw games we provided  a plain, black background to reduce visual clutter using black foam board from Dollar Tree. 

7. ASK! How do you want to play? I could have done a better job of training volunteers of all the play options but it is a goal for next year! 

We didn’t use all the modifications but it was a start for the school. Little changes can make a difference.

Some adapted items require students to hold down on a switch to continue activation. Once they let go of the switch the item or toy stops.

Some examples are bubble blowers, lava lamps, spin arts, Gone Fishin’ Game, dice spinners, or fans.

Check out the Tiny Switchy, a small switch interface that allows you to set a timer for your switch to latch and activate a toy. 

Set a time length from one second to 68 minutes! 

There are more modes and features but check it out on their website. I linked in my stories. This tool is only $35! I ❤️ it!

Create these sensory snow globes from all things Dollar Tree and your craft closet.

These might be a great idea for students who love to hold and look at sensory bottles,  prefers visual experiences or likes to look at photos of themselves. 

Pair with winter songs and use as a shaking musical instrument. 

AND what parent, family or caregiver wouldn’t love them? 

You will  need:
-Hot glue gun 
-Globe from Dollar Tree ( plastic and $1.25) 
-Student picture ( you could have them pose in their hat, cost or with their arms up catching snow ) 
-Fake snow ( a little goes a long way $1.25) 
-anything you want to add like mini trees, sparkles, glitter, foam stickers, pom poms from your craft closet.

Use a mini binder clip to hold down the photo and add what you would like! I opted not to add water as it can get heavy and mess fast. 

Change out theme based on season.

We are back for part ✌🏻 for writing and AAC. Today @aac_innovations and I are talking tips and tool ideas when using Alternative Pencils . 

Takeaways:

Just as there are no prerequisites to AAC, there are no prerequisites to using alternative pencils (this includes knowing letters of the alphabet). Writing is learned through practicing writing. Here are some quick tips to get started:

✏️ Consider using the access mode the individual uses for communication 

✏️Explore keyboards within a robust AAC system, if available

✏️ Find a mode that is easy for them to use and allows a lot of practice and feedback.

Questions? Drop them below and wait for part three!

Hey Santa, a little late but better than never ! 

It’s a freebie! Link in our stories. 

Help your child communicate with Santa this holiday season using this communication bracelet. (Several vocabulary options available). 

Adults and AAC users can wear to model and pair alongside a robust communication system. Here are just a few ideas 💡:

🎄Say hello and goodbye to Santa close up or from a distance ( greetings should be optional) 

🎄Talking about emotions ( Santa can make some really happy and for others really scared) 

🎄Asking questions about his reindeer and making reindeer food ( throw in oatmeal with any glitter ) 

🎄Making a list and talking about what you want for the holidays (we love to pair this with writing activities, using your speech generating device if available)

🎄Place on the tree as an ornament and communication visual to talk about presents

Which activity will you be trying this holiday season? Comment 👇and Happy Holidays!

The Head to Toe Communication resource is reposted in my stories! 

This one page handout can be utilized through a team approach to: 

-identify any movement a student with a complex body or communication needs might have 

-begin to identify potential responses for partner assisted scanning 

-being to plan for potential switch placements 

-gain better insight and understanding for potential access method trials 

-have client or different members of the team fill out to review movement in multiple environments 

-utilize as part of informal AAC assessment

Tag… you’re it! This is a way to create personalized, durable slap bracelets. Inspired by @goboardmaker ‘s original bracelets these are for on the go! 

A VERY special thanks to @_through_hayleys_eyes_ for helping me bring these vinyl stickers to life. Plain white slap bracelets are from Amazon. 

Adults can wear and model too if students choose not to wear. These are a great alternative for tag and chase- a fan favorite game in our motor room and on our playground. These are not always comfortable so throw over a coat, shirt or loop on a backpack. 

A special thanks to our school psychologist for always being a running partner and sporting this with our kids! 

We will be making these at ATIA in my make and take session with the Tobii Dynavox and Boardmaker team.
